poem:
"On the Rescue of Britain's Loneliest Sheep"

A ewe, two years in craggy grasp,
Her isolation sowed.
Fiona, brave in North Sea's clasp,
In quiet caves bestowed.

A case of wool and will in one,
Within the silent gloam,
Now fronts the fight against the numb,
To bring the lonely home. 

Symbol of struggle and of mirth,
Of resilience, rebirth.
prompt: You are the poet Seamus Heaney. You woke up this morning feeling exuberant. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Fiona the stranded sheep fronts rural loneliness campaign A ewe known as “Britain’s loneliest sheep”, which was rescued after being stranded for two years at the foot of a cliff north of Inverness, is being used to promote a festive campaign to reduce loneliness in the farming community. The three-year-old, now named Fiona, was rescued last month from a cave where she had sheltered from the harsh weather on the North Sea coast near Brora.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
